description.narrative:
Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till organisationen Front Line Defenders om totalt 36 000 000 SEK under perioden 2020-2022. För denna period ska Front Line Defenders genomföra sin strategiska plan med fokus på följande områden:
1) Ge snabbt, flexibelt och effektivt 24-timmars akut- och nödstöd i relation till skyddsbehoven hos utsatta mänskliga rättighetsförsvarare. 2) Stärka mänskliga rättighetsförsvarares motståndskraft och kapacitet att hantera sin säkerhet och sitt skydd. 3) Förbättra synligheten för mänskliga rättighetsförsvarare och de positiva effekterna av deras arbete. 4) Stärka det nationella, regionala och internationella skyddet av utsatta människorättsförsvarare.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

description.narrative:
In 2020, Front Line Defenders (FLD) has continued to expand and strengthen its rapid and practical support to Human Rights Defenders (HRDs) at risk around the world. Despite the challenges posed by Covid-19, FLD has continued to provide impactful support to HRDs, adapted programmes and provided support to more HRDs than in any previous year.
During the reporting period, FLD supported a total of 2,604 individuals and 361 organisations in 126 countries. 90% of these HRDs were able to return to or continue their essential work following support from FLDs programmes. 95% of HRDs reported strengthened security as a result of FLD support.
In 2020 FLD continued to grow and strengthen its core programmes in response to increasing needs of HRDs globally. In 2020: • FLD awarded 711 Protection Grants to HRDs at risk in 96 countries worldwide to a total value of €1,759,703. This was an increase of 14% on the number of grants provided in 2019, and the highest number of grants FLD has provided in one year. 99% of HRDs reported that their security was strengthened as a result of a grant. • FLD issued 259 Urgent Appeals & Statements in 70 countries supporting 477 HRDs. 36% of Urgent Appeal cases resulted in a positive outcome for the HRD at risk. 183 cases were raised by FLDs Brussels Office with EU Institutions and Member States, while the UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of HRDs took up an estimated 63 cases from FLD Urgent Appeals. • FLD added 2,587 active HRDs to the database, which now stands at over 15,122 active HRDs in over 165 countries. This represented a 35% increase in the number added in 2019. Of the 2,587 HRDs added to the database an important trend to highlight has been the increase in outreach to HRDs working on corruption, womens rights, LGBTI rights and Indigeneous Peoples Rights. • 96 HRDs from 19 countries participated in 12 trainings on risk analysis and protection planning. Of these, 57 defined themselves as women, 29 as men, and 10 as gender non-conforming. A further 138 HRDs participated in shorter meetings, including webinars. Due to Covid-19, most workshops took place online. 98% of HRDs taking part in Risk Assessment and Protection Planning trainings in 2020 reported that they have created and are implementing security plans. In 2020 FLD reached more HRDs through this programme as a result of recruiting regionally based Capacity-Builders in ECA and MENA regions and being able to facilitate more online workshops and consultations. • 599 HRDs in 59 countries received security advice through 113 consultations and 21 workshops facilitated by FLDs Security Advisor. All HRDs reported improved security as a result of the consultations. • In 2020 346 HRDs (men: 146, woman: 192, gender non-conforming: 8) and 158 organisations from 76 countries were supported by Digital Protection Coordinators. Despite the challenges brought by Covid-19, FLD was able to maintain a relatively similar level of support to HRDs at risk compared to 2019. 99% of HRDs reported that they are actively using the tactics and tools recommended and provided during support and 92% feel more or significantly more secure. • FLD provided support to 16 individual HRDs and 5 groups from 19 countries through the Rest & Respite Programme. All HRDs participating in the programme reported improved well-being following their rest and respite placements. • FLD developed a number of resources to support HRDs to adapt to working from home environments. This included, 'Physical, emotional and digital protection while using home as office in times of Covid-19 Ideas & tips for human rights defenders', and a Guide for HRDs on Secure Group Chat and Conferencing Tools. • FLD published reports on LGBTIQ and Sex Worker Rights Defenders at risk during Covid 19, five editions of Cypher digital comics were published and 12 episodes of the Rights on the Line podcast were produced • FLD led the organisation of the Dublin Human Rights Festival in partnership with Smashing Times, Amnesty International, Fighting Words, ICCL, NWCI, & Trócaire. 10,000 people participated in the events during the ten day period.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
